p: To examine whether the genetic basis of resistance to coevolved and non-coevolved viruses was different we estimated the genetic correlations ( r g ) in their viral loads. These represent the proportion of genetic variance in viral load between pairs of viruses that shares the same genetic causes. In D. melanogaster these were 0.40 for DMelSV-DAffSV, (95% CIs: 0.20, 0.61) and 0.25 for DMelSV-DObsSV (95% CIs: âˆ’0.01,0.47). Similar results were obtained using the D. melanogaster mapping population described below ( Supplementary file 3). In the other species our estimates sometimes had wide credible intervals, but the genetic correlations between coevolved and non-coevolved viruses were mostly below 0.5 ( Supplementary file 3; note correlations are frequently low between pairs of non-endemic viruses too). Therefore if natural selection increases genetic variation in susceptibility to a natural pathogen, there is expected to be a smaller effect on non-coevolved viruses.
